awd_titl_txt: Pleistocene to Recent Environments and Species Distributions on the California Coast
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will take advantage of the exceptional fossil record of coastal California to examine the distributions of living mollusk species over the past ~125,000 years and, using geochemical analysis of their shells, reconstruct the environmental conditions where these species lived.  This approach will make it possible to determine if the ancient distributions of species are consistent with their modern environmental ranges (implying stability) or if some species once lived outside their present-day environmental ranges (implying evolution).  This work will contribute to an understanding of the stability of species' ranges in the face of environmental change, and will provide new data on how the environments and species compositions of economically important coastal ecosystems have varied through time.

The primary goal of the proposed work is to determine whether the thermal niches of northeastern Pacific coastal mollusk species have evolved since the Late Pleistocene, and to test the performance of ecological niche models in hindcasting Late Pleistocene distributions.  Reliable paleoenvironmental data are essential to this task, and a large number of stable isotope profiles and clumped isotope measurements for fossil and modern shells of the common gastropod Callianax biplicata will be generated to reconstruct environmental conditions along the California coast. At each of approximately 20 localities, isotope profiles from recent individuals will be compared with profiles from individuals that lived in the same area during different stages of the last interglacial complex and subsequent highstands (Marine Isotope Stages 5 and 3). Reconstructed temperature and salinity ranges and other paleoenvironmental data will be used to determine whether the mollusk species occurring at each fossil site were occupying environmental conditions similar to those of the geographic regions they now occupy. This work will result in an improved understanding of the determinants of species distributions in space and time, a more detailed reconstruction of California coastal environments during the last interglacial complex, and improved forecasting models for projecting species distributions in an economically critical ecosystem.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
Coastal marine ecosystems are increasingly affected by climate change. Many species are already shifting their geographic ranges, and shifts of greater magnitude are predicted for the near future. Range shifts can have profound impacts on the structure and function of local ecosystems, and consequently there is a growing need to predict marine species responses to current and near-future global change. This need is being addressed by development of increasingly sophisticated species distribution models that use a species’ present-day distribution to make a model of its ecological niche and determine where conditions appropriate for its survival will exist in the future. Species distribution models are very useful, but generally assume (1) that the geographic distribution of a species reflects the physical conditions it can tolerate and (2) that species tolerance ranges will not evolve as the climate changes. To ensure the accuracy of predictions from species distribution models, we must understand not just the present distributions of species but also their distributions during periods in the past which had different climatic conditions. 

The fossil record of California provides an excellent opportunity to study past environmental conditions and geographic ranges. Terraces formed by coastal erosion during past sea levels highstands are a conspicuous feature along this coastline. The most widespread and best preserved terraces formed during the last interglacial complex, which included a full interglacial sea level highstand during a global climate state warmer than present (Marine Isotope Stage 5e, ~125 thousand years ago) and two lower highstands during global climate states cooler than present (MIS 5c, ~100,000 years ago and MIS 5a, ~80,000 years ago). Terrace surfaces are commonly veneered by shallow marine sediments containing abundant fossils of marine invertebrates, especially shelled mollusks (bivalves and gastropods). Previous study of these fossil assemblages has shown that many assemblages include species that no longer occur locally, and that are only found today well to the north or to the south.

As the most recent time in Earth history when global temperatures were warmer than present, the peak of the last interglacial (MIS 5e) can serve as a pre-anthropogenic baseline for a warmer near-future world. We compiled a new database of 22 fossil localities in California that have been reliably dated and used this database to establish baseline expectations for contemporary bivalve species movements by identifying and analyzing bivalve species with “extralimital” ranges —species that occupied the California region during MIS 5e but are now restricted to adjacent regions. We found that 15% of species found in MIS 5e localities have extralimital ranges and currently occupy warmer waters south of California. The majority of extralimital occurrences occurred in paleo-bays, suggesting that these sheltered habitats were more suitable for warm-water species than exposed coastlines during MIS 5e. We also found that extralimital species now tend to occur in cooler, more seasonally productive coastal waters and to occupy more offshore islands when compared with the broader species pool immediately south of California. These findings suggest that dispersal ability and demonstrated tolerance of environmental conditions similar to California’s cool and seasonally productive coastal waters were important influences on which species successully invaded California during MIS 5e. We constructed a machine-learning model to predict which mollusk species may be most likely to invade Californian coastal waters as the climate continues to warm.

To test whether coastal mollusk species tolerated temperatures outside of their observed present-day thermal tolerance ranges during different past climate conditions, we compared local paleotemperature estimates based on the modern-day geographic distributions of co-occurring species with paleotemperature estimates determined from the isotopic composition of modern and fossil shells. Few instructional resources about isotope geochemistry have been developed for high school students and introductory undergraduate courses, and we designed a lesson about isotopes inspired by analyses conducted for this research. We analyzed 6 recent and 26 fossil shells of the intertidal to subtidal gastropod Callianax biplicata, which is ubiquitous in both modern and ancient mollusk assemblages in southern California. Modern shells from 3 sites yielded average growth temperature estimates well within observed local annual temperature ranges. Fossil shells from nearby terraces yielded temperatures indistinguishable from modern for MIS 5e and on average ~2.5˚C cooler than modern for MIS 5a. Seawater oxygen isotope ratios (δ18O) calculated from clumped isotope temperature estimates and shell δ18O values are generally indistinguishable from modern seawater δ18O values in the Southern California Bight. We used these seawater δ18O values to extend our dataset by estimating paleotemperatures from more than 1,000 bulk δ18O measurements of 80 additional C. biplicata individuals. Our results confirm that paleotemperature estimates based on isotopic data and on the modern-day geographic distributions of co-occurring species are generally consistent across multiple sites representing multiple Pleistocene climate states. These findings bolster evidence that thermal tolerance ranges of marine species are generally stable on ~100,000-year timescales.

 


Last Modified: 04/11/2024
Modified by: Seth Finnegan
